statement: Alice has an array a, consisting of n positive integers. The array satisfies the beautiful property that a_i divides a_{i+1} for each 1 â‰¤q i â‰¤q n - 1. Bob sees Alice's beautiful array and is jealous. To sabotage her, Bob first creates an array b of size n such that b_i=a_i for each 1 â‰¤q i â‰¤q n. Then, he chooses a positive integer x and multiplies some (possibly none, possibly all) elements in b by x. Formally, he chooses a (possibly-empty) subset SâŠ‚eq\{1,2,...,n\}, and for each iâˆˆ S, he sets b_i:=b_iÂ· x. You are given an array b, but you don't know array a and the chosen number x. Please output any integer x that Bob could choose, so that multiplying some subset of elements of the correct array a by x would result in array b. It is guaranteed that the answer exists. If there are multiple possible integers, you can output any of them.
input_specification: InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 2Â·10^5). The description of the test cases follows. The first line of each test case contains an integer n (2 â‰¤q n â‰¤q 6Â·10^5)Â â€” the length of the array b.The second line of each test case contains n integers b_1,b_2,...,b_n (1 â‰¤q b_i â‰¤q 10^9)Â â€” denoting the array b.It is guaranteed the array b can be obtained from some beautiful array a and some positive integer x as described in the statements.It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 6Â· 10^5.
output_specification: OutputFor each test case, output any possible value of x (1 â‰¤q x â‰¤q 10^9) on a new line. It is guaranteed at least one value of x exists.
